V436 Per.source: DEBCat and Southworth & Bowman (2022) Table 3. Tess sector 18 analysed with JKTEBOP. Teffs reproduced from Janik et al. (2003)
V436 Per.desc: An eccentric orbit with the secondary eclipse near phase 0.4 and depths of ~0.4 and ~0.15 mag. The long period means only one of each eclipse is observed. Star B is both larger (k~1.1) and more luminous (J~1.04) than Star A which, coupled with partial eclipses and SLF variability, will likely make this difficult to predict.
V436 Per.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

V539 Ara.source: DEBCat and Southworth & Bowman (2022) Table 3. Tess sectors 13 and 39 analysed with JKTEBOP. Teffs reproduced from Clausen (1996).
V539 Ara.desc: An eccentric orbit with eclipses of approximate depth 0.45 and 0.40 mag and the secondary near phase 0.45. Primary fractional radius of 0.22 is beyond JKTEBOP's recommended maximum (0.2). This and the presence of SLF variability make it difficult to fit.
V539 Ara.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

psi Cen.source: DEBCat and Bruntt et al. (2006) Table 2 based on WIRE photometry and JKTEBOP. We have access to TESS sectors 38 & 65 120 s SAP photometry (38 has incomplete eclipses).
psi Cen.label: $\mathrm{\psi}$ Cen
psi Cen.desc: An eccentric orbit with transit depths of ~0.25 and ~0.15 mag and the secondary after phase 0.8. The period of 38.8 d is longer than a single TESS sector; we use both 38 & 65 to give better coverage. We also fix qphot, gravA and gravB for fitting, mirroring the source article.
psi Cen.notes: logLA & logLB derived from R and Teff; qphot, gravA & gravB from paper (pp 654)

V402 Lac.source: DEBCAT and Baroch et al. (2022) Tables 10 and 11. TESS sector 16 analysed with WD.
V402 Lac.desc: An eccentric orbit with the secondary beyond phase 0.6 and significantly shallower than primary despite their similar radii. This will make k and J difficult to predict. Baroch & Gimenez used the WD code for fitting as they considered the components too distorted for JKTEBOP.
V402 Lac.notes: e=0.376 (fixed); rA_plus_rB & k & ecosw & esinw derived from table 11; J approximated from Teff; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

V1229 Tau.source: DEBCat and Southworth et al. (2023), Table I. TESS sectors 42-44 analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V1229 Tau.desc: An inclined, circular orbit with shallow primary (~0.10 mag) and secondary (~0.05 mag) partial eclipses and δ Scuti pulsations. These shallow, partial eclipses present a challange to predicting and fitting k. We use the published spectroscopic light-ratio and LD parameters from Southworth et al. (2023) with sectors 42 to 44 for fitting.

V889 Aql.source: DEBCAT and Baroch et al. (2022) Tables 9 and 10. TESS sector 40 analysed with JKTEBOP and all params published
V889 Aql.desc: A highly eccentric orbit with the secondary eclipse before phase 0.4. This coupled with the stars having similar radii make k and J difficult to predict and fit. As with the published work, we use sector 40 and their spectroscopic light-ratio for fitting. Sector 40 shows some long term trends which our detrending is not removing however this does not appear to be overly detrimental to the predictions or fitting.
V889 Aql.notes: e=0.3750 (fixed); ecosw & esinw derived from table 9; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;
V889 Aql.author: TESS-SPOC

WW Aur.source: DEBCat and Southworth et al. (2005) who use EBOP (with mods to fit rA+rB & k and to use MRQMIN) for fitting of observations from the 1970s. We use V-band fitting results (Table 10). Available TESS sectors 29, 43-45, 60 & 71-73 at 120 s cadence.
WW Aur.desc: An inclined circular orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.64 and 0.55 mag. The combination of partial eclipses and stars of similar radius makes predicting and fitting k and J a challenge. Published work based on legacy photometry wheras we have used TESS data.

V788 Cen.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) who use WD for fitting sectors 10 and 37 (Table 8).
V788 Cen.desc: An inclined circular orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.19 and 0.16 mag.
V788 Cen.notes: e=0.0 & ω=0.0 fixed; rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; J from JKTEBOP fit; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

RR Lyn.source: Rediscussion VII, Table II (with third light). TESS sector 20 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41.
RR Lyn.desc: An eccentric orbit with eclipses of approximately 0.35 and 0.25 mag and the secondary near phase 0.45. Evidence of delta-Scuti & gamma-Dor pulsations. Our labels are taken from the solution with third light.
RR Lyn.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; period set from trial fit;

V362 Pav.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) Table 8 who use WD for fitting.
V362 Pav.desc: An inclined slightly eccentric orbit with shallow transits of approximately 0.2 and 0.03 mag and clear ellipsoidal effect. Star B is signifantly smaller, less luminous and less massive. The published parameters include a significant negative third light value.
V362 Pav.notes: J from JKTEBOP fit; rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

V456 Cyg.source: DEBCat and Van Reeth et al. (2022) Table 1. TESS sectors 14 and 15 fitted with JKTEBOP version 42. SpT and logLA from Bakis et al. (2014).
V456 Cyg.desc: A tight circular orbit of just 0.9 d with distinct eclipses at 0.6 and 0.4 mag. Variability is seen in the light curve from pulsations dicussed in the source article. Both fractional radii are > 0.2, outside the range normally deemed suitable for fitting with JKTEBOP, but it was used in the source article and we are able to achieve a similar fit.
V456 Cyg.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); logLB=0.78(5) from from Bakis+ logLA and Van Reeth+ Light Ratio;

GW Eri.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) who use WD for fitting (table 8).
GW Eri.desc: An inclined circuler orbit with partial eclipses of similar depths at approximately 0.27 mag. With the stars have similar radii and luminosities, predicting and fitting k & J will be challenging.
GW Eri.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; J from trial JKTEBOP fit; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

OO Peg.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XVIII, Table II. TESS sector 55 TESS-SPOC/SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
OO Peg.desc: A circular orbit with clear primary and secondary eclipses of approximately 0.38 and 0.35 mag.
OO Peg.author: TESS-SPOC

CW Eri.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XVII, Table III. TESS sectors 4 and 31 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
CW Eri.desc: A slightly eccentric orbit with clear primary and secondary eclipses of 0.46 and 0.40 mag and evidence of ellipsoidal variation.
CW Eri.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

ZZ Boo.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XII, Table II. TESS sectors 23 & 50 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 42.
ZZ Boo.desc: A circular orbit with similar eclipses at approximately 0.65 mag each. With the stars having similar size and luminosity, predicting and fitting k and J is expected to be a challenge.
ZZ Boo.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

V570 Per.source: Rediscussion XIV, Table II. TESS sectors 18 and 58 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V570 Per.desc: An inclined circular orbit with variability due to starspots, evidence of the ellipsoidal effect and shallow eclipses at approximately 0.11 & 0.1 mag. In the source article a spectroscopic light ratio was used to constrain the fit, and we adopt the published value here.
V570 Per.notes: e=0 & ω=0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; lrat required for better fit (from paper)

AN Cam.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion IV, Table II.  TESS sectors 19, 25, and 26 (timeseries data from FFI) analysed with JKTEBOP version 41.
AN Cam.desc: A highly eccentric orbit with the secondary eclipse near phase 0.8. The analysis in the source article used early TESS FFI observations of 1800 s cadence, here we use sectors 52 and 53 timeseries data (subsequent to publication) which has a cadence of 600 s.
AN Cam.notes: L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;
AN Cam.author: TESS-SPOC

IT Cas.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XIII, Table II (sector 17). TESS sectors 17, 24 and 57 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
IT Cas.desc: An eccentric orbit with low inclination and similar eclipses of approximately 0.7 mag depth. The two components are similar and it expected the k and J will be challenging to predict and fit. The source article recommends fitting the sectors separately due to systematic variation in eclipse depths between sectors; we use only sector 17 for fitting and labels.
IT Cas.notes: Using values from table II, Sector 17; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

V455 Aur.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion V, Table II. TESS sector 20 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41. TESS sectors 60 and 73 released subsequent to publication.
V455 Aur.desc: A slightly eccentric, inclined orbit with eclipse depths of approximately 0.33 and 0.3 mag and a third non-eclipsing component in 4200 d orbit. While the eclipsing components are of similar radius their luminosities differ, with the source article publishing a light ratio of 0.859±0.031.
V455 Aur.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

V505 Per.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion VI, Table II. TESS sector 18 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41. TESS sector 58 observations released subsequent to publication.
V505 Per.desc: An incloned circular orbit with similar primary and secondary eclipses of approximately 0.5 mag. The similarity of the components' radii will likely make predicting and fitting k and J challenging. There is some distortion of the light curve near BTJD 1791.
V505 Per.notes: e=0 & ω=0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw;

AI Phe.source: DEBCat and Maxted et al. (2020), Tables 2 and 3. The Southworth analysis of TESS sector 2 PDCSAP flux (K, JKTEBOP v38, quad LD law).  Teff and subsequently calculated L from Kirkby+Kent et al. (2016)
AI Phe.desc: An eccentric orbit with the secondary occuring before phase 0.5. Star B is significantly larger and evolved with k~1.6. Only sector 2 shows both transits with sectors 29 and 69 having incomplete transits.
AI Phe.notes: J from a JKTEBOP fit with fixed params from run K; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit required fixed period (as in Maxted paper) for reasonable fit - MAE~0.0086

ZZ Uma.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XI, Table II. TESS sectors 14, 21, 41, 47 and 48 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 42.
ZZ Uma.desc: A circular orbit with transits of approximately 0.65 and 0.35 mag and significant variability due to starspot activity.
ZZ Uma.notes: e=0 & ω=0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit with single sector S21, gives MAE~0.037;

QR Hya.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) table 8 who use WD for fitting TESS sector 9. Sectors 36 and 63 released subsequent to publication.
QR Hya.desc: An inclined orbit with partial eclipses of approximately 0.30 and 0.28 mag.
QR Hya.notes: L3=0 (fixed); rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; J from trial JKTEBOP fit; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit with S9 gives MAE~0.027;

V963 Cen.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) who use WD for fitting. Assuming TESS sector 38 was used. Sectors 64 and 65 have since been released.
V963 Cen.desc: A highly eccentric orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.4 and 0.15 mag with the secondary near phase 0.3. Some long period variability is seen in the light curve. The two components are very similar in radius and luminosity which will make predicting and fitting in k and J challenging.
V963 Cen.notes: rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; could not get a good control fit with S38 (MAE~0.3) - best with S65 (MAE~0.02);

V454 Aur.source: Rediscussion XIX, Table II.  TESS sectors 20, 43, 44, 45, 60, 71, 72 and 73 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V454 Aur.desc: A highly eccentric 27.2 d orbit with eclipses of approximately 0.4 and 0.3 mag and the secondary after phase 0.65. It is in an unusual configuration with Star A both smaller and cooler than Star B, as the primary eclipse (of Star A) occurs when the stars are closer in their orbits than the secondary. We use sectors 43-45 to get sufficient coverage for a reliable control fit.
V454 Aur.notes: L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; a very difficult fit - need R19 LD algo+coeffs and multiple sectors to get a reliable fit & prevent JKTEBOP gaussj warnings;

CM Dra.source: DEBCAT and Martin et al. (2024), Table I. TESS Sectors 16, 19, 22-26, 49-52 (all slow) and 56-59 (200 s) analysed with EXOPLANET. SpT, Teff & logL from Morales et al. (2009).
CM Dra.desc: Two M-dwarfs in a nearly circular, slightly inclined 1.27 d orbit. Eclipses are approximately 0.76 and 0.73 mag deep. Lightcurves show frequent flares however these should have little affect on the fit.
CM Dra.notes: Martin values; L3=0 (fixed); just a single sector needed for a good fit as the period is so short;
CM Dra.author: TESS-SPOC
